awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: International Technology Transfers: Adoption or Imitation
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovation and commercialization of technology are the sources of firms’ competitive advantage and countries’ economic growth.  Hence, firms and countries compete and cooperate over frontier technologies through various channels. As geopolitical tension and inequality among countries rise, more research on such interactions in the global economy is needed. This research delves into the dynamics of international technology transfer, specifically focusing on its two major channels: technology imitation and technology adoption. Imitation is unauthorized replication of existing technologies without compensating the innovators, while adoption means legal acquisition of technologies through licensing agreements. These two distinct channels of international technology transfer not only coexist but also interact with each other, shaping the growth and development of countries, and consequently the global economy. This study utilizes unique data on imitation and adoption, and investigates the interplay between these two channels. The derived results will provide important policy implications. First, by documenting how different industries use different modes of technology transfer, the research can inform industrial policy, particularly on promoting innovations. Second, it will help both leader and follower countries better understand the relative costs and benefits of the two channels of technology transfer. Third, by shedding light on the global competition and cooperation in the market for technology, it will help devise more efficient and compatible institutions, including intellectual property (IP) systems. Such institutions can better satisfy various needs of countries and reduce tension between developed and developing countries.

This project starts by constructing a unified endogenous growth model to theoretically explain the mechanisms and assess the impacts of technology adoption and imitation. This framework disentangles the economic forces at play and offers a nuanced understanding of how these dynamic decisions of firms and countries' policies shape their growth trajectories. Next, on the empirical side, the researchers will utilize two proprietary datasets on global patent litigations and patent licensing agreements at the patent- and firm-levels to offer a set of new facts to the field. By taking such direct measures with a granular approach, this research can enrich the understanding of technology transfer patterns across a broad set of developed and developing countries, a critical aspect in today’s highly globalized economy. Lastly, employing a quantitatively-oriented approach, the research will enable realistic assessment of various hypothetical policies, which provides guidance on the optimal industrial innovation subsidies and international agreements of IP protection.

por.por_cntn:
Global technology transfer plays an important role in economic growth. There are two major channels of such transfer, namely technology adoption and technology imitation. The former channel refers to the legal acquisition of existing technologies through licensing agreements, often with associated royalties, while the latter channel involves the unauthorized replication of existing technologies without compensating the inventors. Indeed, these two channels of technology transfer - stealing and sharing - have been contributing to the increasing global political tension. Despite the economic and political significance of the topic, there has not been a comprehensive quantitative framework of technology and growth. This sets the main objective of our project – to construct a unified economic model of technology transfers and to improve our understanding of how these different channels influence global economic growth.

In the first part of the project, we develop an open-economy growth model which incorporates technology imitation and adoption. This model captures how firms make decisions on choosing between these channels and how these activities affect innovation progress. By disentangling the mechanisms underlying technology imitation and adoption, the model provides a clearer understanding of the trade-offs and complementarities between these two channels. One main insight we have obtained is that imitation activities increase when two countries have a wide technology gap, but adoption activities initially increase then decrease as the technology gap becomes wider (i.e., an inverted-U-shaped relationship).

In the second part of the project, we complement the theoretical framework with an empirical analysis. This stage utilizes two proprietary datasets: one covering global patent litigations and the other covering global patent licensing agreements. These datasets provide granular insights into global technology transfer activities, offering an opportunity to measure both imitation and adoption at the patent, firm, and industry levels. These measurements provide the foundation for estimating the quantitative framework.

In the third part of this project, we use the estimated model to decompose the economic growth from different sources for the developing and developed economies. Moreover, by performing counterfactual analysis, we illustrate the relative importance of adoption and imitation regarding global growth performance. Lastly, we carry out two more comparative statics analyses to investigate the effects of real-world innovation policies, such as compulsory licensing policies and the WTO’s TRIPS agreement which aims at strengthening property right protection in developing countries. Quantitatively, compulsory licensing encourages the substitution of imitation with adoption and promotes global economic growth, whereas strengthening property right protection is effective in promoting growth to a certain extent.

The outcomes of this project to date are as follows:

  1. Two working research papers, which comprise a key part of the co-PI's doctoral dissertation; and
  2. Several (completed and scheduled) conference and seminar presentations by the co-PI on the research project.

Expected future outcomes include two peer-reviewed publications describing the results of this project.
